How can I make this onClick event take me to another tsx component I have saved in my components directory?
); } ``` ## Alternative Approaches ### Using Link Component Instead of a Button with onClick, you could use React Router's Link component: ```tsx import { Link } from 'react-router-dom'; ``` ### For Next.js Applications If you're using Next.js, you would use its router: ```tsx import { useRouter } from 'next/router'; function YourComponent() { const router = useRouter(); return ( ); } ``` Choose the approach that best fits your application's setup and routing solution. Is there an approach without touching the main.tsx? # Navigation Without Modifying main.tsx Yes, you can implement component navigation without touching your main.tsx file. Here are several approaches: ## 1. Using Conditional Rendering This approach keeps everything within your current component structure by conditionally rendering different components: ```tsx import React, { useState } from 'react'; import TargetComponent from './TargetComponent'; function YourCurrentComponent() { const [currentView, setCurrentView] = useState('main'); if (currentView === 'target') { return setCurrentView('main')} />; } return (
); } ``` ## 2. Using Context for Application State Create a navigation context that handles which component is visible: ```tsx // NavigationContext.tsx import { createContext, useState, useContext, ReactNode } from 'react'; type NavigationContextType = { currentView: string; navigateTo: (view: string) => void; }; const NavigationContext = createContext(undefined); export function NavigationProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) { const [currentView, setCurrentView] = useState('main'); const navigateTo = (view: string) => { setCurrentView(view); }; return ( {children} ); } export function useNavigation() { const context = useContext(NavigationContext); if (context === undefined) { throw new Error('useNavigation must be used within a NavigationProvider'); } return context; } ``` Then use it in a parent component (not main.tsx): ```tsx // ParentComponent.tsx import { NavigationProvider, useNavigation } from './NavigationContext'; import MainComponent from './MainComponent'; import TargetComponent from './TargetComponent'; function ViewManager() { const { currentView } = useNavigation(); switch (currentView) { case 'target': return ; default: return ; } } export default function ParentComponent() { return ( ); } ``` And in your button: ```tsx // Inside MainComponent.tsx import { useNavigation } from './NavigationContext'; function MainComponent() { const { navigateTo } = useNavigation(); return (
); } ``` ## 3. Using an Existing Router but Only in Component Props If React Router is already set up in your app but you don't want to modify main.tsx: ```tsx import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom'; function YourComponent() { const navigate = useNavigate(); return (
); } ``` The first approach (conditional rendering) is the simplest if you just need basic navigation between a few components without full routing capabilities. ```tsx fundament/src/components/appCard/appCard.tsx import "@digdir/designsystemet-css"; import { Button, Card } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; function AppCard() { return ( App Card This is an app card. ); } export default AppCard; ``` ```tsx fundament/src/App.tsx import React, { useState } from "react"; import AppCard from "./components/appCard/appCard.tsx"; import "./App.css"; import "./components/theme/fundament.css"; import "@digdir/designsystemet-css"; import { Button, Alert, Chip, Checkbox, Field, Input, Label, ValidationMessage, Details, Card, Select, } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; import { Pencil, Save, Trash } from "@byggforsk/fundament-icons-react"; function App() { const [currentView, setCurrentView] = useState("main"); if (currentView === "target") { return setCurrentView("main")} />; } return ( <>

Fundament

Et designsystem for Byggforskserien

Nynorsk Bokmål
En beskjed det er viktig at brukeren ser
En accordion I en dal som alltid ligger dekket av skygger, vokser det blomster som gløder i mørket. De gamle forteller at blomstene er skapt av tårer fra en prinsesse som en gang ble fanget der av troll. De som plukker en slik blomst, sies å få evnen til å se det usynlige, men bare hvis de klarer å komme seg ut av dalen før natten faller på.
En accordion til I en dal som alltid ligger dekket av skygger, vokser det blomster som gløder i mørket. De gamle forteller at blomstene er skapt av tårer fra en prinsesse som en gang ble fanget der av troll. De som plukker en slik blomst, sies å få evnen til å se det usynlige, men bare hvis de klarer å komme seg ut av dalen før natten faller på.

); } export default App; ``` Is there something wrong with this? Your implementation looks mostly correct! You've successfully implemented the conditional rendering approach I suggested for navigating between your main view and the AppCard component. ## There's one minor issue: In your App.tsx, you're using `onBack` prop with the AppCard component: ```tsx if (currentView === "target") { return setCurrentView("main")} />; } ``` However, your AppCard component definition doesn't accept this prop: ```tsx function AppCard() { // No props being accepted here return ( // Component content ); } ``` ## To fix this, modify your AppCard component to accept and use the onBack prop: ```tsx // In appCard.tsx import "@digdir/designsystemet-css"; import { Button, Card } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; interface AppCardProps { onBack?: () => void; } function AppCard({ onBack }: AppCardProps) { return ( App Card This is an app card. ); } export default AppCard; ``` With this change, your navigation will work as expected: 1. In the main view, clicking the "Primary" button navigates to the AppCard view 2. In the AppCard view, clicking the "Back to Main" button returns to the main view The rest of your implementation is correct and follows the conditional rendering approach for navigation without modifying main.tsx. I get this error message: React.jsx: type is invalid -- expected a string (for built-in components) or a class/function (for composite components) but got: undefined. You likely forgot to export your component from the file it's defined in, or you might have mixed up default and named imports. react-jsx-dev-runtime.development.js:479:16 This error message typically indicates that React is trying to render something that's not a valid React component. The most common causes are: 1. A component that doesn't exist or isn't imported correctly 2. A variable that's undefined being rendered as a component 3. Incorrect import/export syntax Let's examine and fix your code: ## Likely Cause and Solutions ### 1. Check your imports in App.tsx Make sure the import path for AppCard is correct: ```tsx // Current import import AppCard from "./components/appCard/appCard.tsx"; // Try this instead (without the .tsx extension) import AppCard from "./components/appCard/appCard"; ``` The `.tsx` extension in the import statement is typically unnecessary and can sometimes cause issues. ### 2. Verify AppCard is exported correctly Ensure your AppCard component is properly exported from its file: ```tsx // appCard.tsx function AppCard() { // Component code } export default AppCard; // Make sure this line exists ``` ### 3. Check for circular dependencies Sometimes import loops can cause this error. Make sure AppCard isn't importing App in some way. ### 4. TypeScript prop interface When you added the onBack prop, did you implement the interface correctly? Make sure the interface is defined correctly: ```tsx interface AppCardProps { onBack?: () => void; } function AppCard({ onBack }: AppCardProps) { // Component code } ``` ### 5. Clear build cache Try clearing your application's build cache: ```bash # If using npm npm run clean # or rm -rf node_modules/.cache # If using yarn yarn cache clean ``` ### 6. Check for any undefined variables in JSX Look through both components to ensure no undefined variables are used in JSX: ```tsx // Wrong {undefinedVariable} // Also problematic {someCondition ? ComponentName : undefined} ``` ### Debugging Steps If the above solutions don't work, try these debugging steps: 1. Temporarily simplify your App.tsx to just return a basic element: ```tsx function App() { return
Hello world
; } ``` 2. If that works, gradually add back components until you find what's causing the error. 3. Check the component rendering right before the error occurred - the error line number in the console should help identify this. 4. Add a console.log to see if AppCard is being imported correctly: ```tsx import AppCard from "./components/appCard/appCard"; console.log("AppCard:", AppCard); ``` Let me know if you find the issue or need further assistance! This is the console log: AppCard: function AppCard() ​ length: 1 ​ name: "AppCard" ​ prototype: Object { … } ​ : function () App.tsx:3:8 The console log shows that AppCard is being imported correctly - it's showing up as a proper function component with the name "AppCard". This means the error is likely occurring elsewhere in your code. Let's dig deeper into common issues that could cause this error even when the import looks correct: ## 1. Check the `onBack` prop implementation The most recent change we made was adding the `onBack` prop. Make sure you've properly updated your AppCard component to accept props: ```tsx // Make sure your AppCard.tsx looks like this import "@digdir/designsystemet-css"; import { Button, Card } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; interface AppCardProps { onBack?: () => void; } function AppCard({ onBack }: AppCardProps) { return ( App Card This is an app card. ); } export default AppCard; ``` ## 2. Check your App.tsx rendering logic Look for any null/undefined values being rendered: ```tsx // In App.tsx function App() { const [currentView, setCurrentView] = useState("main"); if (currentView === "target") { return setCurrentView("main")} />; } // Rest of your code } ``` ## 3. Try simplifying temporarily To isolate the issue, try simplifying your component rendering: ```tsx function App() { // Temporarily disable the conditional rendering return (

Test App

console.log('Back clicked')} />
); } ``` If this works, the issue might be in your conditional rendering logic. ## 4. Check for JSX fragments Sometimes fragment syntax can cause issues. Make sure your fragment syntax is correct: ```tsx // This is correct return ( <> {/* content */} ); // This might cause issues in some configurations return ( {/* content */} ); ``` ## 5. Look for accidentally undefined components In your large JSX block, check if you're accidentally rendering an undefined variable somewhere: ```tsx // For example, this would cause the error return (
{undefinedVariable} // This would cause the error
); ``` ## 6. Check your build/bundler configuration Issues with your bundler (Webpack, Vite, etc.) can sometimes cause this error. Make sure: - Your TypeScript configuration is correct - Your bundler can correctly process .tsx files - You don't have multiple conflicting React versions ## 7. Try a fresh reload/restart Sometimes the development server gets into a bad state: - Restart your development server completely - Clear browser cache with Ctrl+F5 - Try in an incognito browser window Since the import appears to be working correctly, the issue is likely in how the component is being used or in how your build system is processing the files. I get this error when pressing the primary button: Uncaught Error: Element type is invalid: expected a string (for built-in components) or a class/function (for composite components) but got: undefined. You likely forgot to export your component from the file it's defined in, or you might have mixed up default and named imports. Check the render method of `AppCard`. React 22 onClick App.tsx:67 React 11 main.tsx:7 react-dom-client.development.js:13350:27 This error is occurring when you press the primary button, which triggers the conditional rendering of the `AppCard` component. The error specifically mentions "Check the render method of `AppCard`", which suggests the issue is inside the AppCard component itself. The most likely issue is that AppCard is trying to render an undefined component. Let's fix the AppCard component: ## Fix for AppCard.tsx: ```tsx import "@digdir/designsystemet-css"; import { Button, Card } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; import React from 'react'; // Make sure React is imported interface AppCardProps { onBack?: () => void; } function AppCard({ onBack }: AppCardProps) { return ( App Card This is an app card. {/* Make sure you're not using any undefined components here */} ); } export default AppCard; ``` ## Common issues in the AppCard component that could cause this error: 1. **Missing imports**: Make sure all components used in AppCard are properly imported 2. **Incorrect component nesting**: Check if the Card component supports the structure you're using 3. **Custom components used without import**: If you're using any other components within AppCard, make sure they're imported 4. **Conditional rendering issues**: If you have any conditional rendering in AppCard, check if it could render undefined ## Let's also modify the App.tsx section that renders AppCard: ```tsx if (currentView === "target") { // Add a console.log to check if AppCard exists right before rendering console.log("About to render AppCard:", AppCard); return setCurrentView("main")} />; } ``` ## If that doesn't solve it, try this more simplified version of AppCard: ```tsx import React from 'react'; import { Button } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; interface AppCardProps { onBack?: () => void; } function AppCard({ onBack }: AppCardProps) { return (

App Card

This is a simplified app card.

); } export default AppCard; ``` If the simplified version works, then gradually add back the Card components to see which one is causing the issue. The error suggests that something inside the AppCard component is undefined, so we need to focus on fixing what's inside that component rather than the import/export mechanism (which seems to be working based on your console log). ```tsx fundament/src/components/appCard/appCard.tsx import "@digdir/designsystemet-css"; import { Card } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; interface AppCardProps { onBack?: () => void; } function AppCard({ onBack }: AppCardProps) { return (
Card Neutral Most provide as with carried business are much better more the perfected designer. Writing slightly explain desk unable at supposedly about this
); } export default AppCard; ``` IS there any syntax error in the code? Yes, there are two missing imports in your code that would cause the exact error you're seeing: 1. `cat1` is used but not imported 2. `Heading` is used but not imported 3. `Paragraph` is used but not imported Here's the corrected version: ```tsx import "@digdir/designsystemet-css"; import { Card, Heading, Paragraph } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; // Added Heading and Paragraph import cat1 from "../../assets/cat1.jpg"; // You need to add this import for the image interface AppCardProps { onBack?: () => void; } function AppCard({ onBack }: AppCardProps) { return (
Card Neutral Most provide as with carried business are much better more the perfected designer. Writing slightly explain desk unable at supposedly about this
); } export default AppCard; ``` The missing imports are causing React to try to render `cat1`, `Heading`, and `Paragraph` as components, but since they're undefined (not imported), it's resulting in the error: "Element type is invalid: expected a string (for built-in components) or a class/function (for composite components) but got: undefined. You likely forgot to export your component from the file it's defined in, or you might have mixed up default and named imports." 1. Make sure you have an image file at `../../assets/cat1.jpg` or adjust the path accordingly 2. Check that `Heading` and `Paragraph` are available from the `@digdir/designsystemet-react` package - if not, you'll need to import them from the correct location This should resolve the error you're experiencing. ```tsx fundament/src/components/appCard/appCard.tsx import "@digdir/designsystemet-css"; import { Card, Heading, Paragraph, Button } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; import app1 from "../../assets/app1.png"; interface AppCardProps { onBack?: () => void; } function AppCard({ onBack }: AppCardProps) { return (
U-verdier En kort beskrivelse av appen. 25.03.2025{" "}
); } export default AppCard; ``` How can I Make sure this coveres the full screen? To make your AppCard component cover the full screen, you'll need to adjust the styling. Here's how to modify your component: ```tsx import "@digdir/designsystemet-css"; import { Card, Heading, Paragraph, Button } from "@digdir/designsystemet-react"; import app1 from "../../assets/app1.png"; interface AppCardProps { onBack?: () => void; } function AppCard({ onBack }: AppCardProps) { return (
U-verdier En kort beskrivelse av appen. 25.03.2025{" "}
); } export default AppCard; ``` ## Key changes made: 1. **Full viewport dimensions**: - Added `width: "100vw"` to take full viewport width - Added `height: "100vh"` to take full viewport height 2. **Fixed positioning**: - Added `position: "fixed"` to cover the entire screen - Added `top: 0` and `left: 0` to anchor it to the top-left corner - Added `zIndex: 1000` to ensure it appears above other content 3. **Better content placement**: - Added `justifyContent: "center"` to center content vertically - Added `padding: "20px"` to prevent content from touching the edges - Added `boxSizing: "border-box"` to include padding in width/height calculation - Added `overflow: "auto"` to enable scrolling if content is too tall These changes will make your AppCard component take up the entire screen, with the card centered both horizontally and vertically. The Back button will appear below the card. If you want the card to take up more of the available space, you could also modify the card width to be responsive: ```tsx ``` This would make the card more responsive on different screen sizes.
